title: What is the difference between cells and atoms? - Quora

response.answer_text: The cell is the basic unit of life: it is the smallest entity that can be considered a living thing. Atoms themselves, however, are not alive. But cells could not be cells without atoms.  Atoms are the building blocks of everything you see (or can't see!) around you. The Periodic Table of Elements lists all known types of atoms. These different types of atoms, called elements, have very different ways of behaving. They can interact with each other and bond together to form molecules (2 or more atoms). Millions of certain types of molecules combine in specific ways to make the four types of macromolecules found in all cells: proteins, nucleic acid (DNA, etc.), carbohydrates (sugar, starch), and lipids (fat and oils). These larger building blocks, made up of atoms, combine in very specific ways to form a cell... a little sac that has tons of chemical reactions going on inside it, which is the basic definition of life. You and I are made up of trillions of cells, but some organisms are only one single cell. In addition, a cell can be seen with a microscope, whereas individual atoms cannot.

Atoms are considered the smallest structure of matter that still has the properties of a given element. For instance, an atom of gold is the smallest piece of gold that retains the properties of gold. Atoms are made of protons (positive charge) and neutrons (no charge) in the nucleus and electrons (negative charge) in the electron cloud. There are an equal number of protons and electrons in an atoms; hence, atoms have no overall charge. Atoms combine with other atoms to make molecules and compounds. In biology, these molecules may form cellular organelles, which are functional structures within a cell. Organelles may include endoplasmic reticulum, mitochondria, Golgi complex, etc. A cell is the basic unit of structure and function for an organism; or at least for multicellular organisms. Cells are made of several organelles surrounded by a plasma membrane (cell membrane) which helps to regulate what enters/exits the cell. Cells of certain organisms (e.g., plants) will have a cell wall surrounding the cell membrane. In humans there are over 200 different types of cells that have many functions in our bodies. For instance, gametes are sex cells (sperm and egg) that are involved in reproduction. Other cells have many functions including sensory structures, hormone producers, and contractile cells (muscles). So, atoms and cells are quite different from each other.

The term cell originally referred to a small chamber (such as a monks cell) and of course is still used in that way. It was adopted for science by Robert Hooke and his microscope when he magnified a slice of cork by 30 times and saw it composed of many tiny little chambers which he then called cellulae. From there it was adopted into biology as the individual containers for life processes. Within each cell is a small definable spot which was named the nucleus. The term atom came from an ancient greek word implying the smallest non-divisible piece of matter. When more recent concepts about the elements and the Periodic Table were developing it was adopted to mean a single unit of each element. Originally believed to be non-divisible, but we now know that it isn’t but the name stuck. When it was revealed that the atom is composed of smaller parts, and that one part (electrically positive) was located at the centre of the atom, the biological term “nucleus” was adopted for that. So one could say that a cell is a biological entity which is composed of many parts which operate the systems of life at the molecular level, and the molecules of and within the cell are constructed of atoms. A small piece of cork was said to contain over a thousand million (10 raised to power 9) cork cells. A mole of atoms (eg. Iron, 55.85 grams) would contain Avogadro’s number (just over 6 x ten to the power 23) of atoms. So the difference in size of a cell and an atom is enormous. The word cell is used in many other contexts to imply a single unit of something, from a phone battery to a terrorist group ! (The term battery really applies to a connected collection of cells. Of military origin it relates to a collection of defensive gun emplacements). The word atom is also sometimes adopted to imply extreme smallness. Language can be tricky !!

An atom is the smallest part of an element of chemical nature. It is indivisible, i.e. It cannot be further divided into smaller parts. Even though its size is minute, it retains all the original properties of the chemical element. Every atom consists of three subatomic particles, Electrons (negatively charged), Protons (positively charged) and neutrons (no charge).  A cell is a term given to one single unit which is enclosed inside a border. Biologically, it is a unit which forms the structural basis necessary for a being to function. It is hence often referred to as "the building block of life". Organisms can be unicellular, such as amoeba, or multi cellular, such as humans.

Cells are basic units of life while Atoms are basic units of things in the universe… Cells consist of organelles such as mitochondria, ribosomes, nucleus, Golgi apparatus etc… Atoms consists protons, neutrons and electrons… Cells are basically the smallest building block of living tissues… Put enough of the right cells together and you have a biological matter… Some cells could be seen under strong magnifying glass most can be only be seen under a microscope… Atoms on the other hand are usually thought as the smallest building block of elements… Even if that element is a hunk of Copper or Helium in a balloon you cannot see individual Atoms with magnifying glass or even a powerful optical microscope… Infact, no one has actually seen an atom with thier eyes scientists have to study them using techniques that leaves traces behind or trigger instruments… When individual Atoms (which make up an element) combine with others this forms a molecule… Molecules of various substances are present in large numbers even in the smallest cell… So Atoms are much, much smaller than cells… Cells are made up of many atoms grouped into molecules which are collection of atoms… All life is physio-chemical process…

The word nucleus in both the circumstances define radically different yet a bit alike concepts. The word nucleus in terms of a cell is the information storage part of the cell and directs most of the operations of the cell. It can be visualised as the only irreplaceable part of the cell (all organelles are important but without it all these ‘vital' organelles are of zero use) as it is the one which not only guides their creation but also defines their functions. The composition is mostly same for a species’ specific cell type but different for different species. Its size is comparable to that of an average cell (4 to 5 times). It is completely surrounded by cytoplasm and other organelles of the cell. Now taking the case of the word nucleus in the case of an atom. It does not carry information as such but defines a lot of properties of the element it is part of. Its composition consists of just protons and neutrons, i.e., all the atomic nuclei are just permutations and combinations of their numbers. The size of the nucleus in relation to the atom can be visualized by considering it as a pea in the center of our atom the size of Camp Nou (Yeah, I am a Barca Fan). And another point of difference being that Atomic Nucleus is surrounded by only minute electrons (equal to the number of protons and of an even smaller size than protons and neutrons) and empty space while on the contrary cell nucleus is completely engulfed in the cell’s contents. That was all I could think of at the moment. Drop in suggestions (and encouraging up votes if you like the answer).

Cells are the basic unit of life. Atoms are one of the basic units of everything, although you could delve deeper and say that protons, electrons, and neutrons are or even deeper and go for quarks, leptons, and other particles. Basically, atoms make up molecules, which are proteins, DNA, RNA, and lipids in a cell, which cooperate to make up a cell. So the difference is that atoms are a component of cells that are about a million times smaller. See also If cells make up us, what makes up cells?

The cell is considered to be the smallest structural and functional unit of all organisms, and it could very well be classified as “living”, because it has intricate ways of communicating/interacting with and influencing its internal and external environment, while atoms are “non-living”, as they do not exhibit the same level - or even type - of response as cells do. Atoms make up the molecules which eventually make up the cells, but they are not considered biological entities, like cells.

The cell is the basic unit of life: it is the smallest entity that can be considered a living thing. Atoms themselves, however, are not alive. But cells could not be cells without atoms. Atoms are not living things they are cells made up of metal, chemicals, and particles. Atoms are just tiny little things that are in the air. These atoms are so small that you can't even see it that are smaller than 1 speck of dust. Cells and atoms are two totally different things but it's hard to get them mixed up.

An ATOM is the fundamental particle of matter. When it combines, it forms molecules. Many many such molecules form matter. For eg. One oxygen and 2 Hydrogen atoms form a water molecule. When many molecules come together, they form substances, like many water molecules form the liquid water in your cup. Likewise, different molecules come together (although in a much more complicated way) and make a Living CELL. These cells come together and form tissues and those come together to form organs and ultimately, us. So you can say that CELLS are the fundamental units of a living things but they themselves (and all matter)are made up of ATOMS.

An atom is very-very small as compared to a cell. A cell is the structural and functional unit of living organisms; unicellular and multi-cellular animal and plants. All living organisms are composed of cells just as all matters are composed of atoms. As an atom is composed of several components like electron, proton, neutron, etc., a cell is also made up of various components called cell organelles like mitochondria, ribosomes, Golgi bodies, lysosomes, endoplasmic reticulum, peroxisomes, etc. As an atom consists of a nucleus, most cells possess a nucleus suspended in cytoplasm.

Cell is a basic unit of life. Put enough of the right cells together and you have biological matter. Some cells could be seen under a strong magnifying glass, most can only be seen under a microscope.Atoms, on the other hand, are usually thought of as the smallest building block of an element - even if that element is a hunk of copper or the helium in a balloon.

This is similar to asking, how are rocks and castles different? Confused? Let me explain. Castles are huge structures with many elaborate parts and pieces. Many of these pieces are made up of rocks put together in some way. Similarly, cells are huge (when compared to the atom) structures with many complex parts and pieces. Not most, but ALL of the parts and pieces of a cell are made up of atoms. These atoms form together in various ways to give us DNA, proteins, the cell membrane, etc. In short, atoms are related to cells in that they are the basic building blocks of cells (and everything else), but completely different.

Atoms make small things like protein or sugar, or organelles which make up cells, a cell is about 2-3 nanometers long (depending on cell and species) but an atom is at least 1000x smaller and makes up the the things that make up cells. Cells have things to carry out functions but atoms are just very tiny electric charges with charges spinning around them.

Atom is the smallest constituent unit of every matter. While cell is smallest living matter capable of independent existance. In multicellular organisms group of cells form tissue; group of tissue forms organ, then organ system and then whole organism. So cell is basic unit of living organisms. A cell is made up of lipids and proteins whose constituent unit is also an atom.

Both are called “nucleus” which really just means the central and most important part of an object, or organism, or argument, or business, and so on. The nucleus of an atom is pretty simple structurally - just one or more positively charges particles (protons) and neutral-charged particles (neutrons) bound together by powerful forces (the strong nuclear force). The nucleus of a cell is a complex biological structure, with it’s own membrane, housing the cell’s DNA (genes) in long strings called chromosomes.

Cell is the fundamental and basic unit of any living organism Atom is the basic unit any element Cell relates to all the living organisms whether is bacteria, ameoba or big mammals or plants and trees Atoms is unit of minerals such as gold iron etc Both are basic units yet they are different as former is for living organisms and latter for elements ans minerals

Atoms are the smaller particles that are building blocks of all the other ‘cells'.

Gatebiotech - GATE Biotech 2018,Online test series Atom is the basic unit of matter, made up of electrons, protons and neutrons. Atoms make molecules. Molecules make macromolecules. Macromolecules are organised into a cell. e.g. Carbon is an atom, it makes up a molecule like carbon dioxide, monosaccahride or amino acid. These can form macromolecules e.g. polysaccharide, protein, lipids, nucleic acid etc. which are organised into a cell.

A more philosophical answer (purely my own and possibly controversial): If you consider the second law of thermodynamics, that everything moves toward entropy. Then cells are the ultimate physical achievement of the atomic world.  They are able to, in microscopic ways, accelerate the rate of energy transfer toward entropy by using simply regulated catalytic processes to pass energy through states that would demand immense activation energies or would race toward explosions otherwise. The cell has found ways to facilitate mass entropy in days that would take thousands of years on a geological scale. So, yes cells are the basic unit of life...and life is the ultimate incarnation of atomic power.

Size. Atoms are the building blocks of molecules and molecules make up a cell. A cell is made up of organelles and these are made up of various molecular complexes. For example, DNA is made up of chains of complex sugars - made up of carbon, hydrogen, oxygen and phosphate atoms.
Think of an atom as the basic building block of all matter. Cells are made up of many atoms grouped into molecules, which are collections of atoms. All life is a physio-chemical process.

An atom is a single “piece” of an element. So think of like a single Sodium atom. A cell is a discrete building block for an organism, or is an organism itself. It contains the necessary molecules, machinery, and structures for life.
